awd_titl_txt: Preferred binding regions for highly selective and orthogonal multimodal protein separations
awd_abstract_narration:
The development of protein-based medicines is having an increasing impact on treatment of many diseases such as cancer, diabetes, and multiple sclerosis. Example protein-based therapeutics for these diseases include rituxan, insulin, and avonex, respectively, with many more in various stages of discovery and development.  However, the costs of producing these drugs and the challenge of obtaining highly pure drugs with minimal side effects is a major challenge. Often, negative side effects are due to small amounts of impurities that are extremely similar to the desired medicine and thus very difficult to remove. This NSF funded project will develop new methods for efficiently removing these challenging drug impurities from a range of biopharmaceuticals, resulting in reduced production costs, safer medicines and more patient access.

This experimental and computational project will focus on the development of multimodal ligands for chromatographic resins, which will be used to achieve highly selective separations of complex biological products. The new multimodal ligands will increase selectivity by targeting specific regions on protein surfaces, enabling the effective removal of bioproduct related impurities, a critical challenge in biomanufacturing. Experimental characterization techniques will validate molecular-level binding information.  The computational work will predict key binding faces and relative binding affinities and will produce powerful predictive tools for bioprocess development. The development of multimodal systems with unique and targeted selectivities on specific protein surface regions will enable the development of highly effective orthogonal downstream processes guided by molecular level understanding and predictive tools. This will result in reduced costs and improved product quality and safety. Graduate and undergraduate students working on this project will be directly exposed to the state of the art in biophysics, chromatography and molecular simulations.  More broadly, the concepts will be incorporated into both undergraduate coursework and on-line animated movies for the the Molecularium project, the flagship outreach and education effort of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's Nanotechnology Center.

por.por_cntn:
We performed NMR titration experiments between the isotopically labeled Fc fragment and gold nanoparticles (NPs) coated with MM ligands at different ligand densities. The results indicated that the hinge and CH2-CH3 interface were preferred binding regions with higher binding affinities than free-ligand experiments due to cooperativity and avidity effects. We also developed a technique that used DEPC covalent labeling and mass spectrometry to identify the preferred binding patches on proteins bound to chromatographic resins without the need for labeled proteins. We demonstrated that this approach produce binding regions that correlated well with the NMR experiments. The combined biophysical, simulation and chromatographic approaches in this project have enabled us to develop a deeper molecular level understanding of why specific binding faces of proteins have preferred binding to multimodal chromatographic surfaces under different conditions. This has provided significant insights into the binding of complex biological products with important implications for designing efficient processes for the separation of product related impurities from biological products. In addition, simulations performed with multimodal ligands coated SAM surface have indicated that some of these ligands self-associate to form patches of charge and hydrophobicity that are on a length scale that is larger than the individual ligand. This could have important implications in creating more selective separation systems. Further, the quantification of ligand clustering has led us to create surface descriptors that can be used to more accurately predict protein separations in machine learning models. In addition, dewetting free energy calculations have allowed us to gain significant insight into how geometrical presentation and chemical structure impact surface hydrophobicity. We believe these results will enable us to design new ligands that present unique surface patterns and in turn tunable separation processes. We have also initiated dewetting simulations on protein surfaces to enable a more rigorous understanding of the impact of water on these preferred binding domains. Finally, new multimodal anion exchange ligands have been designed, synthesized and evaluated in chromatographic systems. Prototypes with aliphatic or aromatic substituents off the aromatic ring had unique selectivites and enhanced binding affinities for certain classes of proteins and could potentially offer improved selectivity in different modes of operation for downstream bioprocessing applications. Throughout this project several graduate and undergraduate students were educated in the state of the art of downstream bioprocessing, biophysics and molecular simulations.
